revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-07 16:45:18.000000000', 'message': 'fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I77dfc7cc757befdc988016f5f90e4dddada5cc69
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}]
commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I77dfc7cc757befdc988016f5f90e4dddada5cc69
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Fix Dockerfile for Debian Jessie

As we learned in I488445dfd261b7bca322a0be7b4d8ca6105750a3
that the the docker file needed to change, this is a targeted
change to address the docker file contents and not update
the coreos version that is built.

This is being done to fix the stable branch builds.

Change-Id: I7251dc7deac788716adad7b596f25fd1633cf289

Rearrange the pubsub code in plugin.sh

The function marked as common was called from one driver only, while the
other code was duplicated.

(1 comment)

Thanks for the unit test coverage and for exposing the bug.

To me this looks like a good fix to a genuine issue.

Adding bswartz as he knows a lot more about the generic driver than I do.'}, {'account_id': 7102, 'date': '2017-09-05 05:30:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)

In general I wonder if we really want to go in that direction. If you want to block that traffic you could configure the image that way or use cloud-init todo it.
Configuring things inside of an VM with Manila should be really minimal, imo.
-1 is for the comment in the code.'}, {'account_id': 7102, 'date': '2017-09-05 05:30:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 26768, 'date': '2017-09-05 08:54:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Dear Thomas, I disagree with possibility to achieve the same result with modifying the service image because the patch limits SSH access to only one service subnet - the one that share instance belongs to. Via modifying the image you have to allow whole service subnet poll, which still allows another tenants's to access your share instance.

Regarding the /etc/rc.local problem - I agree that it is not global solution for all distros, but as far as I know, there is no solution that works on every system (iptables-persistent syntax differs RH/Debian, systemd is not available on every distro, ...). I suggest to note the option as Debian/Ubuntu/RH/Fedora only. The default service image is Ubuntu (compatible with the patch) and by default this feature is disabled so it cannot break existing installations."}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2017-09-05 09:17:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: -Code-Review

I thing Tom Bechtold makes a good point that this should be done in an OS-agnostic way.  (Generic driver has such issues in other places but that's no reason to add more.)  One approach would be to use neutron security groups.  Just thinking out loud ..."}, {'account_id': 2417, 'date': '2017-09-06 20:13:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

I like the security group approach too. It's a much more standardized approach than trying to get the service image to use a builtin firewall."}, {'account_id': 26768, 'date': '2017-09-07 07:48:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Thanks, I will have a look at it.'}, {'account_id': 26768, 'date': '2017-09-14 12:24:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Published edit on patch set 6'}, {'account_id': 21884, 'date': '2017-09-14 12:25:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

commit_message:
Generic driver - Limiting SSH access from tenant network

Added new config option limit_ssh_access. If set to true the
neutron security groups are set up to block port 22 from other
subnets than service network in service instance.

Change-Id: I3c247ac2c55e5c74dbb0c8e31144bb865fd48710
Closes-bug: #1714288

subject: rocky: release os-traits 0.7.0
messages:
[{'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-06-07 22:15:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-06-07 22:25:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

LGTM, just some compute capabilities traits in this release:

https://github.com/openstack/os-traits/compare/0.6.0...master

Patch version is consistent with what we've done before for new traits:

https://review.openstack.org/480989

os-traits is just a collection of enums so semver on it is kind of weird, I supposed we'd do a minor or major version if we ever *removed* traits, but I don't see that happening."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-08 13:33:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The description of "Add compute capabilities traits" makes it sound like a new feature, which would make this 0.7.0. Is it a feature?'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-06-08 14:55:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> The description of "Add compute capabilities traits" makes it sound
 > like a new feature, which would make this 0.7.0. Is it a feature?

Matt explained in his comment, os-traits is a collection of enums and in the past, releases have bumped only the patch version. It's not as clear how to handle this library wrt to semver.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-08 15:50:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > The description of "Add compute capabilities traits" makes it
 > sound
 > > like a new feature, which would make this 0.7.0. Is it a feature?
 > 
 > Matt explained in his comment, os-traits is a collection of enums
 > and in the past, releases have bumped only the patch version. It's
 > not as clear how to handle this library wrt to semver.

If someone is going to want to require this release in order to have the new enum value, then it seems the enum is the API of the library and adding a new value is a feature.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-06-08 16:07:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > > The description of "Add compute capabilities traits" makes it
 > > sound
 > > > like a new feature, which would make this 0.7.0. Is it a
 > feature?
 > >
 > > Matt explained in his comment, os-traits is a collection of enums
 > > and in the past, releases have bumped only the patch version.
 > It's
 > > not as clear how to handle this library wrt to semver.
 > 
 > If someone is going to want to require this release in order to
 > have the new enum value, then it seems the enum is the API of the
 > library and adding a new value is a feature.

Yeah, I was conflicted between that and trying to be consistent with the last release. I can change it to a minor bump.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-06-08 16:09:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-09 15:31:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-06-11 15:46:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-06-11 16:17:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow+1'}]
